sub_topic: Determining the degree sequence of a graph.
message_1: Consider a graph with 7 vertices and degree sequence {3,3,2,2,1,1,1}. Is this degree sequence possible? If yes, draw a graph that has this degree sequence. If not, explain why not.
message_2:
Yes, this degree sequence is possible. Here is one possible graph with this degree sequence:

1. Label the vertices as A, B, C, D, E, F, and G.
2. Connect A to B, C, and D (A has a degree of 3).
3. Connect B to E and F (B has a degree of 3).
4. Connect C to G (C has a degree of 2).
5. Connect D to E (D has a degree of 2).
6. E, F, and G are already connected to one vertex each, so they have a degree of 1.

The graph can be visualized as follows:

```
  A---B
  |\  |\
  | \ | \
  |  \|  \
  D---E   F
   \
    \
     G
```

This graph has the desired degree sequence {3,3,2,2,1,1,1}.
